mdRecord.dcterms:title: Letter, George Washington to William Pearce, 1794 August 17
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Washington, George, 1732-1799
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Washington is responding to previous correspondence from his farm manager William Pearce. He is pleased to hear of the favorable appearance of the corn and that the ground is in good order for wheat. He desires that the seed from the India hemp growing in the vineyard be saved in due season. He inquires to the appearance of the potatoes. He asked Pearce, if he is satisfied, to allow Kate (wife of Will) at Muddy hole her wish to serve the Negro women (as a granny) on the estate. Washington reads in the George Town Gazette that holders of shares in the Potomac Company (treasurer William Hartshorn) are to give 12 pounds sterling per share--GW holds 5 shares. Washington comments on the turnover of overseer Crow and possibly McKoy and how best to replace the positions as well as his disdain with overseers Green and Butler. Autograph letter signed, 4 pages.
